title: Why can't we feel our hair and nails growing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi Daniel. One reason is that there are no peripheral nerves in hair and nails. And there’s no peripheral nerve tissue because, although hair and nails are modified skin, they’re not living tissue. We can feel pain at hair follicles if we pull hair out. That’s because hair follicles are living and are an accessory of the skin. It would be painful to have a nail pulled out. That’s because nails grow out from the nail root under the cuticle. The root is the only living part of the nail. So it could be asked why can’t we feel our hair follicles and nail roots growing new cells. We don’t feel our cells proliferating. There’s no biological advantage to that, no biological reason for it. If we sensed cellular mitosis, it wouldn’t be limited to hair and nail cells — we would feel cellular mitosis throughout our body taking place 24/7. And it does take place 24/7. I don’t think we could sleep, eat or focus or do anything but feel the mitosis.

Because they grow so slowly we dont notice, and hair and nails are dead once they come through. We dont notice our skin renewing when we cut it, or do we. I started thinking about it, when I first grew a beard it itched once it started coming through. Any cut hurts a bit and itches when its getting better. I shave my head which itches a bit when it starts growing. Perhaps itching slightly is a sign of renewal? Its only a guess.
